void_function_no_parameters.comment: By default, Ruby returns whatever the last statement returns. Ruby always returns a value, even if it's nil.

void_function_with_parameters.comment: Ruby always returns a value, even if it's nil.

void_function_variable_parameters.comment: Ruby always returns a value, even if it's nil.

return_value_function_no_parameters.comment: It's common practice to end method names that return booleans in a question mark, eg valid?, enabled?, nil? Parenthesis at the end of the method are optional.

return_value_function_with_parameters.comment: Ruby returns the value of the last expression by default. `return val` is optional.

anonymous_function_no_parameters.code:
-> { expression }
# or...
lambda do
  expressions
end
# or...
Proc.new do
  expressions
end
anonymous_function_no_parameters.comment: You can do any way, normally lambda or Proc.new is used for multi-line expressions.

anonymous_function_with_parameters.code:
->(param) { expression }
# or...
lambda do |param|
  expressions
end
# or...
Proc.new do |param|
  expressions
end

anonymous_function_variable_parameters.code:
->(*params) { expression }
# or...
lambda do |*params|
  expressions
end
# or...
Proc.new do |*params|
  expressions
end
